questions.text: During summer, a teenager experiences muscle and joint pain along with a slight fever. He also observes a rash on the side of his upper leg, leading his mother to take him to the clinic. What is the most likely cause and method of transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Borrelia burgdorferi/tick bite.

The “bull’s-eye” appearance of the skin lesion, the fever, muscle and joint pain, and the fact that the patient lives in an endemic area support a clinical diagnosis of tickborne Lyme disease caused by B. burgdorferi.

questions.text: A patient injured her skin while gardening, leading to an intensely painful infected lesion. Culturing the wound revealed Gram-positive cocci that were β-hemolytic on blood agar. When hydrogen peroxide was added to the colonies on nutrient agar, effervescence occurred. What enzyme causes this bubbling?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Catalase

This enzyme facilitates the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen gas, resulting in the bubbles observed on the plate. It is produced by bacteria as a defense mechanism against hydrogen peroxide generated by neutrophils. In contrast, β-lactamase is an enzyme that hydrolyzes the β-lactam ring found in penicillin and related antibiotics. Coagulase, produced by Staphylococcus aureus, induces clot formation. Staphylokinase, also referred to as fibrinolysin, is produced by S. aureus and functions to dissolve fibrin clots.

choices.text: Immune evasion through IgA protease production

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl developed a fever, sore throat, cough, and malaise shortly before leaving an orphanage. A few days later, she was taken to the emergency room in respiratory distress. Examination showed significant bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, an inflamed throat, and a thick, grayish exudate on the tonsils. Some of the exudate had loosened, revealing bleeding from the underlying mucosal tissue. The causative agent was isolated on tellurite medium. What virulence factor is responsible for the pathogenesis of this infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Toxin-mediated inhibition of protein synthesis This case describes diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. This bacterium produces a toxin that disrupts protein synthesis by inactivating elongation factor-2. It does not possess any of the other listed virulence factors. Unlike Neisseria, C. diphtheriae does not secrete an IgA protease. As a Gram-positive bacterium, it does not contain lipopolysaccharides. The M protein, an important virulence factor, is produced by Streptococcus pyogenes, while C. diphtheriae is not known to produce coagulase, which is associated with Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is hospitalized with community-acquired pneumonia. Blood and sputum cultures grew the a-hemolytic catalase-negative, bile-soluble, optochin-sensitive organism shown in the photograph. It showed an intermediate degree of resistance to penicillin. What are the other important virulence factors of this organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Capsule and pneumolysin.

The organism described in this case is Streptococcus pneumoniae. It is an important cause of communityacquired pneumonia and strains range in sensitivity to penicillin from fully susceptible to intermediately susceptible to highly resistant. Virulent strains of S. pneumoniae, also called pneumococcus, produce a thick, polysaccharide capsule that provides protection against complement activation and phagocytosis. Pneumolysin is a unique cytotoxin elaborated by pneumococci. It induces pores in host cell plasma membranes following binding to cholesterol residues, thereby damaging ciliated respiratory epithelial cells and neutrophils.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female college student experiences a sudden fever of 104 °F and severe headache, with physical examination revealing nuchal rigidity and papilledema. A Gram stain of her cerebrospinal fluid is provided. What is the cause of her infection?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Neisseria meningitidis This case indicates meningitis. While all the listed organisms can cause meningitis, N. meningitidis is unique as a Gram-negative diplococcus. It is a significant cause of meningitis among children and young adults, especially in crowded living conditions like dormitories.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy on the high school wrestling team shows several firm, flesh-colored, umbilicated papules, measuring 3 to 4 mm, on his chest, arms, and groin. He is clinically diagnosed with molluscum contagiosum. What is the viral cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Poxvirus

The viral etiology of molluscum contagiosum is C: Poxvirus. This condition is caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus, which is a member of the poxvirus family. It typically presents as firm, flesh-colored, umbilicated papules and is commonly seen in children and adolescents, particularly those involved in activities that may facilitate skin-to-skin contact, such as wrestling.

questions.text: A woman from West Rajasthan presented with an ulcer accompanied by redness on her right leg. Microscopic examination of a biopsy taken from the ulcer's edge revealed organisms with darkly stained nuclei and a kinetoplast. What is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Leishmania tropica

This clinical presentation is indicative of cutaneous leishmaniasis. Leishmaniasis is a gradually progressing disease caused by a protozoan parasite belonging to the genus Leishmania. The disease is transmitted through the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly, which injects flagellated promastigotes into the host's skin. In India, this disease is primarily found in regions such as Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

questions.text: A young man recently back from the USA experiences fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral hilar and mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Culture on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar shows white to light brown fluffy colonies, and lactophenol blue staining reveals characteristic structures. What is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Histoplasmosis

The findings suggest Histoplasma capsulatum, which is known for its tuberculate macroconidia with finger-like projections. Histoplasmosis, also known as Darling's disease, is caused by this dimorphic fungus, primarily found in the Ohio River valley and lower Mississippi regions of the USA, as well as in West Bengal, India. The fungus thrives in humid, acidic soil rich in bird or bat droppings and is transmitted through inhalation of spores released when soil is disturbed. Once inhaled, the spores are engulfed by alveolar macrophages and convert into yeast forms.

choices.text: Growth of other commensals is suppressed

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with purulent urethral discharge and painful urination for 2 days. Which reason explains the use of the following medium to grow the suspected pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Growth of other commensals is suppressed

The medium in question is Thayer-Martin, used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It contains antimicrobials that inhibit the growth of other commensal bacteria. In males, gonorrhea typically presents as acute urethritis, characterized by mucopurulent discharge and burning during urination.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented with firm, rough-surfaced papules on her genital area. Histopathological examination of the lesion shows findings consistent with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Papilloma virus infection

The clinical presentation and the presence of koilocytic changes in the tissue are characteristic of a papilloma virus infection. Koilocytic cells are squamous epithelial cells that exhibit perinuclear cavitation, enlarged nuclei, coarse chromatin, and irregular nuclear contours. They typically have a rim of condensed cytoplasm that creates a halo or cleared appearance around the nucleus. Koilocytes are commonly associated with cervical cancer, precancerous cervical lesions, genital warts, and cancers of the anal and oral regions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is experiencing treatment-resistance to shown bacteria. You intend to send a sample of his urethral discharge to the laboratory for culture and sensitivity testing. Which transport medium would you choose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stuart’s medium Stuart's medium is the appropriate transport medium for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis. This semisolid, non-nutrient medium is designed to inhibit microbial growth while allowing the survival of the microorganisms present for an extended period.

questions.text: A patient has been experiencing epigastric pain for over six months, which has not improved with over-the-counter medications. An endoscopic biopsy of the gastric tissue revealed curved, Gram-negative rods that are oxidase-positive and grow at 37 degrees Celsius in microaerophilic conditions along with shown finding on Warthin - Starry stain. What is the most likely organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Helicobacter pylori

This clinical presentation is indicative of peptic ulcer disease linked to Helicobacter pylori. H. pylori is a motile, Gram-negative rod with lophotrichous flagella and is notable for its urease production, which aids in its diagnosis. The primary habitat for H. pylori is human gastric mucus, with the gastric antrum being the most common site of colonization. The infection typically remains localized to the gastric mucosa or in areas of gastric metaplasia and heteroplasia in the duodenum.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with low-grade fever. On examination, a characteristic slapped cheek appearance is seen on the face as shown. Which of the following describes the genetic makeup of the pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Single-stranded DNA

Based on the clinical presentation and the classical slapped cheek appearance, the condition is due to Parvovirus infection also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease. Parvovirus is made up of single-stranded DNA.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and a rash. A urine examination reveals shown appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cytomegalovirus

The most likely causative agent is cytomegalovirus (CMV), given the clinical symptoms and the identification of owl's eye cells in the urine. CMV is the largest member of the herpesvirus family and is associated with various medical conditions.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with high fever, muscle aches, and fatigue, following a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain about 20 days earlier. Blood tests show eosinophilia, and muscle biopsy reveals encysted spiral larvae. What is the likely organism responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Trichinella spiralis

This scenario, along with the biopsy findings, points to Trichinella spiralis. Known as the pork worm, infection occurs from consuming undercooked pork. Initial symptoms include diarrhea and abdominal pain, while later stages present with fever and muscle pain as larvae migrate to muscle tissues. The larvae typically infect active muscles and become calcified after several months. Treatment involves albendazole and steroids to manage inflammation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents to your clinic with symptoms of diarrhea and abdominal pain that have persisted for the past 4 days. Stool examination shows eggs that can float in a saturated salt solution. Which organism is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hymenolepis nana

The clinical history and stool microscopy indicate an infection with Hymenolepis nana. Its eggs have a thin outer membrane, an inner embryophore containing a hexacanth oncosphere, and are filled with yolk granules. These non-bile stained eggs float in a saturated salt solution.

questions.text: A veterinarian comes to the clinic with symptoms of fever, malaise, and headache. Upon examination, a lesion is noted on his face. He subsequently develops sepsis. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the organism responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increase in cAMP  

The clinical details, including a black, necrotic eschar with surrounding edema on the veterinarian's face, strongly indicate cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis. The toxin operates by raising cAMP levels.

questions.text: A HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool is given below. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cryptosporidium

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain – positive oocysts as seen in the given image is suggestive of Cryptosporidium.

questions.text: A child presented with diarrhea, cough, and wheezing for the past 6 months. He is underweight and stunted for his age. Blood tests showed mild eosinophilia. The appearance of larva in the stool specimen is shown below. The likely cause is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Strongyloides stercoralis

The given clinical scenario and the image showing rhabditiform  larvae indicates infection by Strongyloides stercoralis. The worm is ovoviviparous. The eggs contain fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.

questions.text: A male sewer worker experienced intermittent fever for 2 weeks, followed by jaundice and purple-blue skin spots. He later developed hematuria, neck stiffness, and showed abnormal hepatic and renal function before dying. What special stain was used to examine the hepatic tissue section?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Levaditi silver impregnation

The clinical presentation suggests leptospirosis, caused by Leptospira, which is best visualized in tissue sections using Levaditi’s silver 
impregnation method. This zoonotic disease occurs through contact with the blood or urine of infected animals in contaminated water, with rats being common reservoirs.
